paragraphs.text: Lookie there. I didn’t even make you wade through the whole post to get to the meat of the thing.
paragraphs.name: fc1b
7c2a
paragraphs.text: But I do, sometimes, wish that I’d been able to experience her living her passion. I wish that I’d woken up in the morning to her typing at a novel or a poem. Or that I’d heard her plinking away at a guitar or working a pottery wheel late into the night.
Lookie there. I didn’t even make you wade through the whole post to get to the meat of the thing.
paragraphs.name: fc1b
4bd2
paragraphs.text: What I’m saying is that living in your passion, even ten minutes a day, is a gift you give your family. Set that teeny, tiny goal and protect it. Meet it, every day.

paragraphs.name: 588a
paragraphs.text: Get one of those folding TV tables and turn your toilet into a mini-office. (This sounds like I’m being silly, but I live with my husband, two kids (one has autism), and my parents-in-law who both have dementia. Sometimes the bathroom is my sanctuary. The only room with a door I can lock.)

61a720b16ce8.title: Hi Shaunta, I’m going to keep this post handy when I wonder why I get up to write before my kids…

paragraphs.name: 4cff
paragraphs.text: Hi Shaunta, I’m going to keep this post handy when I wonder why I get up to write before my kids get up. I habitually think about what it means to be a model for living your passions and think that it might be a healthy component for motherhood (and fatherhood!) that we sometimes forget to incorporate.

8002e11025ad.title: Thank you for this wonderful post.

paragraphs.text: Thank you for this wonderful post. I have known about the importance of writing daily, no matter what, for many years, but your post gave me a new perspective to understand why exactly that’s so important. As a single parent, it can be especially hard to commit to writing daily when snow days, sick days, teacher professional development days, and…
Really nicely said, Shaunta. And profound, too. When one focuses so precisely on the goal that there are no more excuses, then forward movement is the result. Thanks for your thoughts!

paragraphs.name: b9e9
paragraphs.text:
Jon Rozek
www.jonathanrozek.com

content.subtitle: So far, it has been very helpful. And my italian greyhound loves sitting in my lap while I do so. All around excellent.

paragraphs.name: 2b4e
paragraphs.text: My tiny goal (successfully 2 days in) is to journal on a daily basis again. Instead of going through emails while eating my breakfast, I’ve put the electronics away and pulled out an old notebook I haven’t written in regularly in over 10 years.
So far, it has been very helpful. And my italian greyhound loves sitting in my lap while I do so. All around excellent.

paragraphs.name: 5a23
paragraphs.text: Infinitely this! I have one of those breakfast trays with legs that I use on the couch for research/writing time. It cost me about 10 bucks but really really works when I need to get sh*t done!

paragraphs.text: Shaunta, this is such a lovely post, especially the story about your mom, who delayed her dreams until the right opportunity showed up (which did not happen). Such a powerful reminder for the rest of us. I am sure that we all oversetimate what we can do in one day and underestimate what we can do in one year, sticking to tiny steps. Thank you.

4736b5200594.title: Like everybody, I have a schedule that seems to want to always keep me from writing.

content.subtitle: Plus, now that I’ve started writing on Medium (and elsewhere), I’m actually writing a lot more than just 750 words a day. Starting with a…

paragraphs.text: Like everybody, I have a schedule that seems to want to always keep me from writing. There’s always a deadline for work or a dog that needs walking or dishes to be done, etc. It was bothering me that I wasn’t writing much at all and I set a pretty modest writing goal and just forced myself to try to write do it every day. As the days passed and I…

paragraphs.name: 4e8c
paragraphs.text: You got my attention. Heck! I have to set that ten minutes goal. It is the least I can do. Ten minutes is realistic. You can’t procrastinate that.

paragraphs.name: adc9
paragraphs.text: Wonderful piece. I appreciate that.

be6fb5631e70.title: Shaunta, I wish that I had not given up my love of drawing and painting when I had my children and…

paragraphs.name: 91a5
paragraphs.text: Shaunta, I wish that I had not given up my love of drawing and painting when I had my children and started my career. Here I am in my early 60s reigniting my passion of the arts as if I have been in a coma for the past 40 years. At first it was overwhelming, but now I have learned to embrace even 10 minutes a day to pursue my love of art.

paragraphs.text: writing daily is a joy, it is my treat to myself to put thoughts down on paper and then put them into some sort of format. I also enjoy reading medium posts and commenting on them- does that count as writing lol ?
